Course Description: This is an introductory course on algorithms for computational biology. The goal is to make students familiar with the basics of algorithm designing techniques and their application in solving problems of molecular biology. Students will be trained for developing their own algorithms for solving real life biological problems. Hands on training will be given for commonly used softwares for genomic data analysis.

Mandatory: Familiarity with structural programming and molecular biology.
Desirable: Familiarity with structural programming and molecular biology.
Other: Familiarity with structural programming and molecular biology.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Design algorithms for computational biology problems using algorithmic techniques like greedy, divide and conquer, dynamic programming etc.
Course Outcomes.CO2: Analyze algorithms from computational complexity point of view.
Course Outcomes.CO3: Utilize common bioinformatic tools for solving practical problems.
Course Outcomes.CO4: Implement algorithms using common data structures like arrays, graphs and trees.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Background, algorithms, complexity, brute force, recursive techniques
Molecular biology primer, different data types. Anecdotes of breakthroughs.

Sequence alignment: pairwise, global, local, multiple sequence alignments, sequence database search, suffix trees; dynamic programming based algorithms, space efficient alignment using divide & conquer.
addressing challenges with pseudoknots, application of dynamic programming.
Genome assembly - Overlap Layout Consensus and de Bruijn graph assembly, greedy algorithm for shortest common superstring.
Regulatory motif discovery: brute force, greedy algorithms, the Pattern Branching algorithm

Analysis of bulk and single cell expression; data: normalisation, dimension reduction, clustering, biclustering, BiMax, a divide and conquer algorithm, differential expression analysis, pseudo time analysis using minimum spanning tree.
Network analysis: clique finding, regulatory networks, co-expression networks, causality analysis (mutual entropy and partial correlation)

Textbook: Kleinberg, Jon, and Eva Tardos. Algorithm design. Pearson Education India, 2006.
Jones, Neil C., and Pavel Pevzner. An introduction to bioinformatics algorithms. MIT press, 2004.
